urn:contentItem:58CS-NXH1-DYTG-216R-00000-00Forest fire contained2013-05-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisAPg. A005Forest fire containedThe Canberra Times

Forest fire contained Firefighters contained a five- hectare blaze in Uriarra Pine Forest off Brindabella Road on Friday.

The fire in bushland east of Uriarra Village was reported soon after 1.20pm and contained by 4.30pm.

The fire was burning in a westerly direction away from Uriarra Village, the Emergency Services Agency said in a statement.Ten tankers and two light units were sent to respond and no properties were threatened.

Crews remained on the scene for several hours after the fire was brought under control, to strengthen containment lines and conduct mopping-up operations.

urn:contentItem:5MJG-BMX1-F0J6-J2SD-00000-00Bago forest fire | photos, video2017-01-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisFRONT PAGEPg. 1Bago forest fire | photos, videoLetitia Fitzpatrick

Firies believe a fire which burned 16 hectares of Bago State Forest on the edge of Wauchope was started by arsonists.

The flames were spotted in Pembrooke by a staff member from NSW Forestry Corp at 5.10pm on Thursday December 29.

Firefighters condemned those who started the blaze as reckless of people's lives.

urn:contentItem:5XYM-6YF1-DYG0-900Y-00000-00<published>2020-01-12T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:54:54Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Karen Sweeney<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 12 AAP - The death of a 40-year veteran firefighter while battling a blaze in Victoria's alpine region has taken the state's bushfires death toll to four.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Wonthaggi father-of-two Bill Slade, 60, was struck by a tree while working at the edge of a fire at Anglers Rest near Omeo on Saturday.<br/>   Fire danger warning levels largely remained steady across Victoria's northeast and East Gippsland on Sunday.<br/>   An emergency warning remained in place on Sunday evening for a fire near Mount Buffalo, while 10 other watch and act warnings were active in Victoria's bushfire-ravaged east and northeast.<br/>   Premier Daniel Andrews and Prime Minister Scott Morrison both offered condolences to Mr Slade's family on Sunday.<br/>   "He was much loved, an absolute mentor to many many people and we send our best wishes to Carol and his two kids, his broader family, friends, and his Forest Fire Management Victoria family," Mr Andrews said.<br/>   Mr Slade's death shows the fires remain a dangerous environment, he said.<br/>   "Mr Slade's death is a significant loss for the forest firefighting family and the whole community," Forest Fire Management Victoria chief Chris Hardman said Sunday morning.<br/>   Mr Hardman said their firefighters would continue to be deployed despite the dangers.<br/>   ?We have to be out there ... it?s a long time before the risks around these fires are over,? he said.<br/>   Temperatures remained mostly in the low 20s across the state on Sunday, ahead of a week that will see mercury rise.<br/>   Milder conditions, however, have not changed the message from emergency services to remain vigilant.<br/>   ?Even though we?ve got fairly benign weather conditions, this is yet another reminder where we?ve got fairly fairly active fire out there that people need to stay across conditions in their local area,? Emergency Management Victoria Commissioner Andrew Crisp said.<br/>   More than 1.3 million hectares have been razed since November 21, while 286 homes and 400 other buildings have been damaged.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XYM-6YF1-DYG0-900Y-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-12</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="335"/><timeReceived>7:13 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:5PTG-WFT1-F0J6-J0TV-00000-00Warm, dry conditions force forest fire ban2017-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Warm, dry conditions force forest fire ban

Campfires and barbecues using wood, charcoal or other solid fuels have been banned in most State forests until further notice, to reduce the risk of bushfires. Forestry Corporation of NSW's Senior Manager of Stewardship, Kathy Lyons said campers and picnickers could continue to bring and use gas stoves during the ban, except during declared total fire bans. The fire season has commenced early this year due to the very dry conditions. Failure to comply with the Solid Fuel Fire Ban carries a maximum penalty of $2200.

urn:contentItem:5RW1-P951-F0J6-J0NW-00000-00CSI deems Kuitpo Forest fire not suspicious2018-03-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11CSI deems Kuitpo Forest fire not suspiciousDani Brown

Following investigations by Crime Scene Investigators, a fire at Kuitpo Forest early on Sunday morning has been deemed not suspicious.

Eight Country Fire Service (CFS) crews and police attended the fire at the forest just off Dashwood Gully Road, about two kilometres south-east of Kangarilla, just after midnight on Sunday, March 11.

The fire was brought under control just after 2am with about 500 square metres of scrub and plantation pines destroyed.

CFS remains on the scene to mop up and monitor the area in case of any flare-ups.

A SAPOL spokeswoman said CSI deemed the fire not suspicious after attending the fireground on Sunday.

Early investigations indicate it may have been a campfire which got out of control.

Anyone who sees suspicious behaviour should call Police Assistance on 131 444.

urn:contentItem:57FS-TV81-F0J6-J2W1-00000-00Firefighters are continuing to mop up a forest fire2013-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisDAILYPg. 9Firefighters are continuing to mop up a forest fire

Firefighters are continuing to mop up a forest fire burning in the ACT's south.

The fire is burning close to Mount Ginini in the western region of Namadgi National Park and is under control.

The ACT Rural Fire Service has four units on the scene to fight the 26-hectare forest fire. Meanwhile, a helicopter reconnaissance flight will monitor whether there is any fire still burning at Sentry Box and Rendezvous Creek within Namadgi National Park.

urn:contentItem:5MJ8-CP91-F0J6-J4XK-00000-00'Ten individual ignition points': Bago forest fire2017-01-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3'Ten individual ignition points': Bago forest fireLetitia Fitzpatrick

A fire which burned 16 hectares of Bago State Forest on the edge of Wauchope was started by arsonists.

The flames were spotted in Pembrooke by a staff member from New South Wales Forestry Corp on December 29.

Forestry firefighters, along with Fire & Rescue Wauchope, and Rural Fire Service crews from Lake Innes and Sancrox, battled the blaze.

Protection forester Mick Wilson said there appeared to be 10 individual ignition points.

  A 41-year-old man is being questioned by police over an out of control and unpredictable bushfire in state forest northeast of Perth.
   A watch and act alert has been issued for the blaze in Julimar State Forest in the Shire of Toodyay, which was reported at 7.30am on Thursday and is being tackled by 100 firefighters.

   Roads have not been closed but motorists are asked to avoid the area.

urn:contentItem:5CKY-98R1-JDKC-R189-00000-00SLOW-MOVING FOREST FIRE BURNS AT CLOSEBURN2014-07-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisSLOW-MOVING FOREST FIRE BURNS AT CLOSEBURN

BRISBANE, Queensland, July 7 -- The Queensland Department of Community Safety issued the following news release:

Queensland Fire and Emergency Services is advising:

A medium-sized (200mx200m), slow-moving forest fire is currently burning at Closeburn in the area around McDowells Rd and Mt Samson Rd. Five rural fire crews, three urban fire crews and Moreton Bay Regional Council staff are at the scene and more crews are responding to the fire which broke out around 2am.

Rural crews are currently working to control the fire and urban crews are providing structural protection and liaising with residents. Residents are asked to review their Bushfire Survival Plan.

Residents should consider taking precautionary measures including:

* Put on protective clothing

* Drink lots of water

* Move car/s to a safe location

* Close windows and doors and shut blinds

urn:contentItem:7W6J-67R0-YBDY-R032-00000-0011,000 flee forest fire2009-07-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 1211,000 flee forest fire

ABOUT 11,000 people were evacuated yesterday as a huge forest fire raged in Canada.

Helicopters, air tankers and firefighters were attacking the 3.5sq km blaze near the Glenrosa subdivision of Kelowna, 275km east of Vancouver. At least three houses were destroyed, but no casualties were reported.

A further 6000 people in the West Kelowna subdivision were on evacuation alert.

Assistant Fire Chief Lou Wilde hinted strongly the fire had been deliberately lit. ``I'm quite certain lightning wasn't a factor,'' he said.

A second fire was burning at Rose Valley Reservoir, threatening 1500 homes, and a third fire was burning at Fintry.

urn:contentItem:54VS-5C31-JC0X-K43W-00000-00NZ:Forest fire threatens NZ homes2012-02-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSNZ:Forest fire threatens NZ homesAUCKLAND Feb 1

  A large forest fire in New Zealand's Wairarapa region is threatening homes, even though firefighters say they've managed to contain it.


   Firefighters are stationed near the four homes, 200m from the fire near Otahome Road, about 15km south of Castlepoint.
   Two fires raged from 4am (1am AEDT) on Wednesday in the 130-hectare pine forest in the southeast corner of North Island and have scorched about six hectares.
   Speaking from the scene, Wairarapa principal rural fire officer Phill Wishnowsky told AAP although the fire has been brought under control, there was still cause for concern.
   "There is always room for the potential for something to go wrong," he said.
   "At this point the fire is contained and under control."
   Mr Wishnowsky said high winds whipping the area were fanning the flames and stopping the fire service from using a helicopter to tackle the blazes.
   Winds were gusting up to 120km/h early on Wednesday.
   About 20 firefighters using seven appliances have been battling the fires.

urn:contentItem:5XYK-7FH1-DYG0-94YT-00000-00<published>2020-01-12T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:54:54Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Karen Sweeney<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 12 AAP - A father of two killed battling a blaze in Victoria's alpine region was a 40-year veteran firefighter.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Wonthaggi father of two Bill Slade, 60, was working edge of a fire at Angers Rest, near Omeo, when he was struck by a tree on Saturday.<br/>   He's being remembered for his legacy as one of the community's longest-serving and fittest firefighters, an as a mentor.<br/>   Mr Slade's death is a significant loss for the forest firefighting family and the whole community, Forest Fire Management Victoria chief Christ Hardman said Sunday morning.<br/>   He is survived by wife Carol and children Steph and Ethan. FFMV and Parks Victoria have sent staff to support Mr Slade's family and colleagues.<br/>   ?Although we do have enormous experience in identifying hazardous trees, sometimes these tree failures can?t be predicted,? Mr Hardman said.<br/>   ?It would have been a traumatic experience for everybody on that taskforce.?<br/>   Mr Slade had worked on major fire incidents in the past including the 1983 Ash Wednesday bushfires.<br/>   His 40 years service was recognised in a presentation by Parks Victoria chief Matt Jackson in November.<br/>   ?Bill was a much loved colleague, friend and member of the Wonthaggi community. He?ll be sorely missed by Parks Victoria,? Mr Jackson said.<br/>   Mr Slade?s death comes after fellow forest firefighter Mat Kavanagh, 43, died on duty when his vehicle crashed on the Goulburn Valley Highway on January 3.<br/>   Mr Hardman said despite the dangers their firefighters would continue to be deployed.<br/>   ?We have to be out there ... it?s a long time before the risks around these fires are over,? he said.<br/>   ?I think we need to be really clear unless we get really significant rains ... 100-150mm of rain, we?re going to be in this for the long haul."<br/>   Premier Daniel Andrews and Prime Minister Scott Morison both offered condolences to Mr Slade's family on Sunday.<br/>   "He was much loved, an absolute mentor to many many people and we send our best wishes to Carol and his two kids, his broader family, friends, and his Forest Fire Management Victoria family," Mr Andrew said.<br/>   His death shows the fires remain a dangerous environment, he said.<br/>   An emergency warning has remained constant for a fire near Mount Buffalo and Emergency Management Victoria Commissioner Andrew Crisp said it?s strongly suggested people leave toward Porepunkah.<br/>   ?Even though we?ve got fairly benign weather conditions, this is yet another reminder where we?ve got fairly fairly active fire out there that people need to stay across conditions in their local area,? Mr Crisp said.<br/>   Mr Andrews visited Orbost in East Gippsland onSunday with Bushfire Recovery Victoria chairman Ken Lay to announce a $14.4 million program linking fire affected communities with free support programs including mental health and financial counselling.<br/>   "To all those people who are doing it tough, please don't try to soldier on on your own," Mr Lay said, urging people to contact case workers.<br/>   Mr Andrews said recovery will take time but a dedicated support person could help make the process easier.<br/>   More than 1.3 million hectares have been razed since November 21, while 286 homes and 400 other buildings have been damaged.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XYK-7FH1-DYG0-94YT-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-11</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="539"/><timeReceived>1:29 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:5FKC-31N1-JDKC-R0MP-00000-00CREWS CONTINUES TO PATROL FIRE AND MOP UP HOTSPOTS IN FOREST FIRE IN VALENTINE AREA2015-03-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisCREWS CONTINUES TO PATROL FIRE AND MOP UP HOTSPOTS IN FOREST FIRE IN VALENTINE AREA

BRISBANE, Queensland, March 22 -- Queensland Fire and Emergency Services issued the following news release:

A forest fire in the Valentine area, near Water Park Creek and Orchard Road, is currently burning safely within containment lines.

Crews are continuing to patrol the fire and mop up hotspots.

There is no current threat to property.

Fourteen crews and a number of aircraft will be working to keep the fire contained throughout the day.

Residents are encouraged to remain vigilant and monitor conditions. For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

urn:contentItem:56W8-8DM1-F031-X36F-00000-00Pokolbin Forest fire contained2012-10-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisPokolbin Forest fire contained

A bushfire burning in the Pokolbin State Forest on Wollombi Road has been contained.

The blaze has burnt out 55 hectares of land and required the assistance of bulldozers and water bucketing helicopters to bring it under control.

The Rural Fire Service says firefighters will use cooler conditions today and tomorrow to strengthen containment lines ahead of an expected hot day on Thursday.

The RFS continues to monitor five other fires in the Singleton area.

12</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MADRID -- At least a dozen firefighters were killed when they were trapped by a forest fire raging along a 17km front in central Spain.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>REUTERS</p></bodyText></section><p>The death toll from one of Spain's worst firefighting disasters could be as high as 14.</p><p>The fire broke out on Saturday in a reserve in the Guadalajara area east of Madrid after visitors did not put out a barbecue.</p><p>It spread out of control after scorching thousands of hectares of pine trees and bushland.</p><p>Parched by a heatwave and the worst drought since the 1940s, much of Spain is like a tinder box.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4J74-1F50-TX53-B25S-00000-00Thousands flee raging forest fire2006-02-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 23Thousands flee raging forest fireUS Los Angeles, Monday

FIRES have swept through an area near Los Angeles forcing 1500 home evacuations and cutting roads. Helicopters dumped water to slow the spread of the wind-whipped forest fire in hilly Cleveland National Forest 40 kilometres from central Los Angeles.

The fire had consumed 400 hectares by midday local time, Orange County fire chief Stephen Miller said.

In 2003, wildfires in California killed 22 people and destroyed 3000 homes as they burned 300,000 hectares of land.

urn:contentItem:5CHW-CP01-F0J6-J0RD-00000-00Shearing shed lost in forest fire2014-06-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisPg. 17Shearing shed lost in forest fireEmily Baker

A FIRE burning through Thursday night in remote state forest at Bell Bay was attended by the fire service yesterday.

The blaze was discovered by two State Emergency Service volunteers in the early hours of yesterday morning.

Fire services said a shearing shed was destroyed by the time they arrived.

Crews continued to check for hot spots throughout the afternoon before investigators arrived.

·Fire services attended two shack fires at George Town about 5.33pm yesterday.

Police were still investigating the Mount George Road fires late last night.

urn:contentItem:5DGM-RYT1-F031-X0PJ-00000-00Bundaleer Forest fire season work underway2014-10-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisBundaleer Forest fire season work underway

Fire season preparations are continuing in the Bundaleer Forest, which has reopened to the general public.

The forest was closed after it was devastated by a bushfire in January last year due to concerns damaged trees were a risk to public safety.

The acting chief executive of ForestrySA, Jerome Coleman, said preparations for the upcoming fire season include annual track maintenance work, clearing fallen trees and weed spraying.

"The community can be rest assured that ForestrySA is continuing its preparations as it always has done," he said.

"At the moment we've got two crews working in the Bundaleer Forest clearing track and they'll be moving up into the Wirrabara area."

A fire burning in bushland in the East Boyd State Forest yesterday, near Edmund Road, has been contained.

The Rural Fire Service, State Forests and National Parks and Wildlife Service firefighters responded to calls about smoke sightings.

It is thought cause of the fire was a lightning strike.

Firefighters are patrolling the area today.

urn:contentItem:59T6-7CD1-F12F-F2FC-00000-00FIRE CREWS WORK TO CONTAIN GRASS AND FOREST FIRE AT SOUTH OF MARYBOROUGH2013-11-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisFIRE CREWS WORK TO CONTAIN GRASS AND FOREST FIRE AT SOUTH OF MARYBOROUGH

BRISBANE, Queensland, Nov. 9 -- The Queensland Department of Community Safety issued the following news release:

Fire crews are still working to contain a grass and forest fire burning near Cooloola Coast and Boonooroo roads, Tuan Forest, south of Maryborough. The fire is approximately 500 hectares in size and started around 11.15am. The fire is located in forestry area and is slowly moving towards the township of Tuan. There is no immediate threat but residents are urged to remain vigilant. Motorists are asked to drive to conditions and residents should keep their doors and windows closed and if required, respiratory medications close by. If people are concerned their home is under threat they should call triple zero (000) immediately. controlled</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MADRID: After a non-stop 26 hours, firefighters yesterday brought under control a forest fire that raged near Madrid forcing the evacuation of thousands of people.</p><p>The 5000 people from the historic town of San Lorenzo del Escorial, including patients of a nearby hospital and holiday-makers from a camping site, who had to be evacuated were returning home.</p><p> None of the homes had been affected by the fire that charred at least 500ha of pine forest, police said.</p><p> More than 50 Spanish army troops and 500 volunteers were in the area from early yesterday to help fight the blaze.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Some homes were also threatened.</p><p> In other Olympics news, squabbling over ceremonies will stop the Olympic flame from touring both sides of the divided eastern Mediterranean island of Cyprus this week.</p><p> Organisers hoped the flame would travel through the Greek-Cypriot and Turkish-Cypriot sides, split since a 1974 Turkish invasion after a brief Greek-inspired coup.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4K0F-7500-TX52-F25C-00000-00Cloud-seeded snow fights forest fire2006-05-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 10

AP

Cloud-seeded snow fights forest fire

SHANGHAI: Firefighters used cloud-seeding technology to bring on a snowfall that helped extinguish a raging forest fire in northern China.

Snow fell for about an hour after shells containing silver iodide were fired into the sky above the burning forest near Hulunbuir, a settlement in the sprawling Inner Mongolia region north of Beijing. Firefighting official Ah Yongge said the snow appeared to have helped control the fire.

''There were clouds in the sky already, which you have to have to bring on a snowfall,'' he said. Fire broke out in the area on Tuesday, burning 8300ha of camphor pines.

urn:contentItem:5H7D-90V1-F0J6-J17N-00000-00Darkes Forest fire lights up night2015-10-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisNEWSDarkes Forest fire lights up nightANGELA THOMPSON

FIRE crews are keeping watch over a section of bushland at Darkes Forest that went up in flames Tuesday night.

The blaze began about 6pm in circumstances that are still being investigated.

It consumed 15 hectares of bush as 54 RFS firefighters grappled with dense vegetation and limited access.

It was 2am before the crews could go home.

They returned early Wednesday to keep watch for flare-ups and remain at the fireground.

Illawarra Rural Fire Service superintendent Richard Cotterill said the blaze began in fairly benign conditions but - in dense vegetation - was difficult to suppress.

''Gaining access to fire tracks was not easy,'' he said.

''We had 12 [trucks] up there. Because they couldn't access areas for direct suppression the fire behaviour was quite intense in some areas.

''It necessitated pulling back [crews] at times.''

Firefighters carried out back burning to contain the blaze.

Asked if the fire could be the result of a lightening strike, Supt Cotterill said there were several possible causes.

''We've got a fire investigator looking into it further this afternoon.''

Fire crews have worked through the night to bring a bushfire at Darkes Forest under control.

SUMMER picnickers in the Dandenong Ranges received a fright yesterday morning when a bus caught fire in Sherbrooke. The Country Fire Authority was alerted to the blaze at 11.50am. urn:contentItem:7W8H-K0W1-2RYX-132G-00000-00Two die in forest fire as arson feared2009-07-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 34Two die in forest fire as arson feared

MADRID: Two men have died in a huge forest fire which officials suspect was started deliberately in central Spain's Castilla y Leon region.

One of the victims, a bulldozer driver sent to put out the fire, was killed when he lost control of his machine. A 63-year-old retired teacher, Javier Heras, also died when he became trapped in his home by flames.

It is estimated forest fires across Spain have claimed at least eight lives during the northern summer, amid soaring temperatures.

The blaze in a mountainous region near the town of Avila devoured over 300 hectares of woodland in just five hours.

The fire was 150km west of Madrid. Towns and a monastery in the area were evacuated.

urn:contentItem:5XV2-P061-F0J6-J516-00000-00Mount Lang fire prompts advice2019-12-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Mount Lang fire prompts adviceAlexander Darling

FOREST Fire Management Victoria has advised people to avoid the Grampians Tourist Road, with a bushfire at Mount Lang in Grampians National Park not yet under control.

In a message to Grampians, Jimmy Creek, Mafeking, Mirranatwa residents released at 3.55pm on Wednesday.

The organisation said the fire could be seen from the road and Halls Gap.

It said the fire did not represent a threat to surrounding communities.

As the Advertiser went to press, the bushfire was 93 hectares in size and 23 emergency service vehicles, machinery and aircraft were working in the area.

The fire has been burning since Sunday, December 22.

Forest Fire Management Victoria said they would issue another update by 4pm on Thursday or as the situation changes.

The Country Fire Authority declared a very high fire danger warning for the Wimmera on Thursday.

urn:contentItem:59T6-7CD1-F12F-F2FG-00000-00FIRE CREWS WORK TO CONTAIN GRASS AND FOREST FIRE NEAR COOLOOLA COAST AND BOONOOROO ROADS2013-11-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:54ZLexisNexisFIRE CREWS WORK TO CONTAIN GRASS AND FOREST FIRE NEAR COOLOOLA COAST AND BOONOOROO ROADS

BRISBANE, Queensland, Nov. 9 -- The Queensland Department of Community Safety issued the following news release:

Fire crews are still working to contain a grass and forest fire burning near Cooloola Coast and Boonooroo roads, Tuan Forest, south of Maryborough. This fire has broken containment lines and is slowly moving towards the township of Tuan. Firefighters will be conducting backburning this evening on the outskirts of the township to protect the township. There is no immediate threat but residents must remain vigilant and call triple zero (000) if they are concerned. There will be a significant smoke hazard in the area tonight and residents who suffer from respiratory conditions should take the necessary precautions. Residents should keep their doors and windows closed and motorists should drive to conditions. xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Plane helps quell S-E forest fire</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A BOMBER aircraft on standby in the South-East quickly helped contain</p><p nitf:lede="true">a forest fire yesterday.</p><p>It made several foam drops on the Glencoe Forest fire, containing it</p><p>to a small stand of pine trees in less than 30 minutes.</p><p>Country Fire Service and forestry crews also fought the fire, which</p><p>began about 11am.</p><p>Due to the extreme fire danger in the Lower South-East yesterday, the</p><p>bomber aircraft was on standby at Mt Gambier Airport.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata
